column4: Cleaning up: COVID-19 vaccine will not derail disinfectants market, industry exec says
column5: NORTHWICH, England, Nov 26 (Reuters) - Vaccines against COVID-19 will take some steam out of the market for hygiene products, but demand will remain above pre-pandemic levels as frequent hand-cleaning is here to stay, an executive at Ecolab, a leading firm in the sector, said on Thursday.
column6: Ecolab has supplied Oxford’s vaccine-makers, supermarkets such as Tesco and England’s National Health Service (NHS) with products during the pandemic this year, and supplies three million commercial sites globally.
column7: In the summer, it signed a deal with the NHS to supply 5 million litres of hand sanitiser, which Sam De Boo, Ecolab’s President for Western Europe, said was the firm’s biggest one-time customer order.
column8: But with two COVID-19 vaccines on course for possible approval in Britain before the end of the year, that demand will be tempered.
column9: “It will of course go down from these current peak levels (but) we do believe it will be higher than 2019,” De Boo told Reuters on Thursday.
column10: “For hand hygiene, we think that still the market will be 30% to 50% higher than it used to be. But of course, where we currently see an explosion of ... five to ten times more - that will normalise.”
column11: Ecolab said on Thursday that two products - a hand-rub and a surface disinfectant - had been shown to be specifically effective against SARS-CoV-2 following tests in Germany.
column12: The World Health Organization says the coronavirus can be spread via surfaces though the main route is through droplets.
column13: British health minister Matt Hancock has said society should start getting back to normal after Easter, but that increased hand-washing was a “no regrets thing” that would become commonplace.
column14: De Boo said: “In the past, when you did not see, let’s say any dirt or any soil, you felt it was clean and it was trusted. People who have ... lived through this pandemic, I think, will have a very different understanding on that going forward.
column15: “I think there is a mindset change.” (Writing by Alistair Smout; editing by Stephen Addison)

column4: Apergy to acquire Ecolab's upstream energy unit in a $3.9 billion deal
column5: HOUSTON (Reuters) - Oilfield equipment provider Apergy Corp will acquire Ecolab Inc’s upstream energy business in a tax-free deal valued at about $3.9 billion, the companies said on Thursday.
column6: The combination will expand Apergy’s global business in drilling equipment and completion services for oil and gas producers, a sector that has been hit as U.S. shale companies have been drilling fewer new wells.
column7: Smaller oilfield services companies have been cutting staff and reducing activity in U.S. shale while seeking to expand outside of North America. Well completions in Texas, home of the largest shale field, are down about 16% from a year ago.
column8: The deal is worth $3.89 billion based on Apergy’s closing price on Wednesday. Apergy also will assume $492 million in debt from the acquisition, which gives the deal an enterprise value of about $4.4 billion .
column9: Analysts at investment bank Tudor, Pickering, Holt & Co said the price tag “appears lofty at first blush but we’d argue this isn’t out of the expectations fairway for a business like this”.
column10: The deal will bring stable oilfield chemicals revenue, helping balance the volatility of equipment sale, the investment bank said.
column11: Apergy shares were up 6% at $32.52 in early trading. Ecolab’s shares gained 2% to $189.93.
column12: Ecolab and Apergy shareholders will own about 62% and about 38% of the combined entity respectively.
column13: Under the deal, structured as a Reverse Morris Trust transaction to save on tax, Ecolab will complete the spin-off of its upstream energy business, ChampionX, to its shareholders and then immediately merge the unit into a subsidiary of Apergy.
column14: Apergy Chief Executive Officer Sivasankaran Somasundaram will head the combined company, which will be headquartered in The Woodlands, Texas, and will have operations in over 55 countries.
column15: The combined company is expected to generate pro-forma revenue of about $3.5 billion and adjusted core earnings of about $615 million before synergies in 2019, the companies said.
column16: Centerview Partners LLC and Lazard served as financial advisers and Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP was the legal counsel to Apergy, while BofA Securities served as exclusive financial adviser to Ecolab, with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP as legal counsel.
